abstract.p: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection remains a major public health problem in Vietnam. Recent studies have found that prevalence of current HBV infection (HBsAg+) ranges from 10% to 20% in the general population and 20% to 40% among injecting drug users and HIV+ patients. However, HBV prevention and control in Vietnam relies heavily on universal infant vaccination program and HBsAg screening for blood donors. Currently, HBV prevention and control is underfunded by the government and receives little support from international agencies. HBV-related liver disease will continue to create a heavy burden for public health in Vietnam in the next several decades unless appropriate interventions are undertaken urgently. Establishment of a national strategy for HBV prevention and control is crucial to develop and implement effective interventions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) remains one of the most common and serious etiology of liver disease despite the effective HBV vaccine introduced 25 years ago. Worldwide, of 350 million people chronically infected with the virus, 600 000 persons die each year because of either acute or chronic consequences of the infection.1 In Vietnam, an estimated 8.4 million people live with chronic HBV infection resulting in 23 300 HBV-related deaths in 2005.2 In many areas, prevalence of HBsAg positivity is as high as 15% to 20% of the general population.3-8 Owing to late introduction of HBV vaccine, large population (84 million people estimated in 2006) and inadequate public health responses against the disease, HBV infection remains a major public health problem in Vietnam and could be a huge challenge in the future. However, HBV infection has not been considered as a serious public health issue as it should be. HBV-related liver disease has not been listed in the top 10 of either highest mortality or morbidity diseases, according to health statistics from the Ministry of Health. The reason is that HBV-related morbidity and mortality are classified in different categories, including acute and chronic hepatitis B, liver cirrhosis and hepatocellualr carcinoma (HCC), or liver failure. Hepatitis B infection is not notifiable in Vietnam; therefore, it is difficult to have collective data at national level regarding morbidity as well as mortality. This article will review the epidemiology of hepatitis B infection in Vietnam and identify the current issues and future challenges regarding prevention of hepatitis B–related liver disease to assist policy makers in combating the disease.

sec.title: Epidemiology of Hepatitis B in Vietnam
Literature Review
sec.p: Epidemiological data on HBV at national level are very limited. To have an overview about epidemiology of HBV infection in Vietnam, literature review was conducted based on both electronic database and manual search. Publications in English were retrieved from Medline and Pubmed database using keywords “hepatitis B virus,” “hepatitis B infection,” and “hepatitis B” in combination with “Vietnam” without any limitations. For publications in Vietnamese, because of the unavailability of electronic version of local publication, a manual search was conducted in main libraries in Vietnam, including National Library, the Central Institute of Medical Science Information, and libraries of several medical universities, including Hanoi Medical University, Military Academy of Medicine, and Thai Binh Medical University. In addition, the lists of references in selected publications were scanned for additional articles. Since number of Vietnamese publications on HBV infection is limited, any articless reporting HBsAg prevalence with or without other markers were selected. Studies with sample size less than 100 were not included unless the study populations were children or high-risk groups. No attempt was made to contact authors for clarifications or further details of data as corresponding authors were not indicated and no authors’ contact details were provided in any of the local publications.

sec.title: Prevalence of Hepatitis B Infection in Vietnam
sec.p: Prevalence of HBsAg in healthy subjects ranges from 5.7% to 24.7% depending on study setting and study subjects. There was no temporal trend in relation to prevalence of HBV markers of the general population (Table 1 and Figure 1) as only cohort born after introduction of universal HBV vaccination program are protected from HBV infection whereas at least 10% of the population has already been infected with HBV. Thus, reduction in HBsAg prevalence due to vaccination would only be observed in the cohort born after introduction of universal infant HBV vaccination program. Further study on the effect of universal HBV vaccination program in Vietnam should be conducted. Most previous studies reported HBsAg prevalence within a range of 10% to 20% whereas prevalence of anti-HBs and anti-HBc were less reported. One study of children born before HBV vaccination program found anti-HBs prevalence of 5.3% but in the general population or healthy subjects it ranges from 16% to 41% (Table 1). Although anti-HBc is considered as the main indicator for past infection of HBV, only few studies provided such data. In the studies conducted by Chau,9 Hipgrave et al,3 Chu et al,10 the prevalence of anti-HBc was between 50% and 55%. However, it was reported to be 70% to 75% by La11 and Nguyen et al,8 except one study provided anti-HBc prevalence of 6% in children 3 to 6 years old. This discrepancy could be explained by the differences in study methods and study population between the studies. Compared to other countries in the region where universal HBV vaccination program was introduced in early 1980s or 1990s, prevalence of HBV infection in Vietnam remains high. Prevalence of HBV infection in Taiwan, for instance, has substantially reduced, particularly in teenagers, after implementing universal and catch-up HBV vaccination programs covering age from infants to teenagers in 1986.12-15 Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore, where universal HBV vaccination program was implemented earlier have also achieved a reduction in HBV prevalence, particularly in the cohort born after introduction of the HBV vaccine.16-18

sec.p: Several studies investigated prevalence of HBV infection in high-risk groups, including health care workers (HCWs), blood donors, injecting drug users (IDUs), and patients with or without liver diseases (Table 2). About 12% to 18% of health care workers are positive for HBsAg. Comparison of HBsAg prevalence between HCWs and general population was made in 2 studies,23,38 which reported insignificant difference (P > .05). The results should be interpreted with caution as the sample sizes were small in these 2 studies. Nevertheless, in high endemic regions, early acquisition of HBV through vertical or early life transmission means many health care workers may already be infected with HBV before they started working in the health sector. HCWs in Vietnam have been encouraged to be vaccinated; however, it is neither compulsory nor provided by the government. Notably, HCWs with chronic HBV infection are not forbidden to perform exposure-prone procedures such as open surgery.

sec.p: The prevalence of HBsAg in voluntary blood donors was similar to that in the general population, ranging from 11.5% to 18.2%.23,27,41 In the study by Pham et al,42 the HBsAg prevalence among commercial blood donors was only 3.0% as they had previously given blood and therefore they were screened for HBsAg. Nevertheless, the prevalence of anti-HBs in this study was 48.7%, similar to that in other studies on healthy subjects.

Unlike HCWs and blood donors, hospitalized patients with or without liver diseases have higher rates of HBsAg prevalence (Table 2). One in every 4 to 5 patients without liver disease was positive to HBsAg. Similar results were found in patients with multiple blood transfusions. The prevalence of anti-HBc in patients receiving blood transfusion was double than in the general population (80% vs 40%). Nearly 50% of patients with hepatitis attributed their disease to HBV. Of patients with liver cirrhosis or HCC, up to 80% were positive for HBsAg (Table 2). These figures strongly suggest that HBV is a major cause of liver diseases in Vietnam. Co-infection between HIV and HBV has been reported in several articles with prevalence of HIV-HBV co-infection among IDUs infected with HIV in the range of 12.3% to 24.7%.48-50 There is very little information on HBV/HCV co-infection. It was reported as 1.2% among patients with hepatitis, 7.7% among patients with liver diseases but much higher in HIV-infected patients (19.1%) and IDUs (25%).22,44,47,51

Although a number of studies were conducted to investigate HBV prevalence, very few studies were community based, and used multistage random sampling methods.3,8,9,19,20 Most of studies focused on different groups and used convenience sampling methods for subject recruitment from health check-up seekers, students, school children, pregnant women, patients’ visitors, government staff or workers. High-risk groups, including heath workers, blood donors, IDUs, and patients with or without liver diseases were also included.

To estimate age-specific prevalence of HBsAg positivity and to minimize selection bias, we selected only studies that were community based and had similar classification of age groups. Three community-based studies, including 2 conducted in the north (one in urban and one in rural area) and one in the south (rural area) met these criteria.8,9,19 The highest prevalence was seen in age group of 30 to 39 years in both genders (19.3% for male and 14.0% for female) followed by age group of 40 to 49 years (18.6% and 13.4%, respectively; Figure 2).

sec.p: Genotype A-G has been found in the serum of Vietnamese patients infected with HBV.52 Genotype B, C, and D are more common in patients with chronic hepatitis, liver cirrhosis, or HCC,26,52-54 whereas genotype A is more frequent in asymptomatic carriers.52 A study of 350 serum samples of asymptomatic HBV carriers, chronic hepatitis B and liver cirrhosis and HCC caused by HBV found that genotype C (25%) is the most common followed by genotype D (20%) and genotype A (18%).52 Genotypes C and D have been documented as independent factors for development of cirrhosis and HCC compared with genotype B whereas patients with genotype B have higher risk of advanced disease compared with those with genotype A.52,55-58

sec.title: Risk Factors for HBV Infection in Vietnam
sec.p: It is well known that vertical transmission is common in high endemic countries such as Vietnam. However, horizontal transmission also plays an important role in spreading HBV. High prevalence of HBsAg in children, 9.3% to 14.1%, suggested that perinatal and early childhood transmission is a major mode of HBV transmission in Vietnam.20,32,36 The rate of current or previous infection was found to linearly increase with age from 19.6% in infants to 79.2% in adults in one study3 and from 51% in the age group of 16 to 19 years to 82% in age group of ≥60 years in another study,8 suggesting ongoing HBV horizontal transmission. A study by Hipgrave et al3 reported that the current infection (HBsAg+) rates were 12.5% in infants, 18.4% in children, 20.5% in adolescents, and 18.8% in adults, indicating that HBV infection is attributable to not only vertical transmission but also, significantly, to horizontal transmission.3 Studies from Hong Kong and Thailand found that ear piercing in females and family history of carriers were independent risk factors of HBV infection among school children.59,60

Risk factors for HBV infection were reported by a number of studies; however, several studies only used univariate analysis and some defined HBV infection as HBsAg+ and anti-HBs+ but not anti-HBc+.9,39,61 Therefore the results should be interpreted with caution. Factors associated with increased risk for HBV infection defined as HBsAg+ and/or anti-HBc+ were only reported in one study in which the authors found that age 60 years or older, district of residence, hospital admission, and history of acupuncture were risk factors for HBV infection.8 Two community-based studies using multivariate analysis reported risk factors for HBsAg+ as household contact with a person with liver disease, reuse of syringes, or history of medical injection and sharing of razors.8,20 IDUs are known as being at high risk of HBV acquisition. Among HIV-positive IDUs, sharing drugs through frontloading (eg, using a syringe and needle to transfer drugs to another syringe’s barrel when the plunger is withdrawn from the distal end), is associated with HBV infection.49 It is important to note that only 11% of IDUs in this study reported having been vaccinated against HBV.

One cross-sectional seroprevalence study conducted in the north mountainous area of Lao Cai province, involving different ethnicities,20 found that nearly a third of households (29.5%) participating in the study had at least one person currently infected with HBV. Kinh and Day ethnicity had the highest prevalence of HBsAg (nearly 13%) whereas Dao and Phu La had significantly lower prevalence (4.1% and 4.7%, respectively). Although in this study none of the Hmong people was positive with HBsAg—probably because of small sample size (only 30 people), HBsAg prevalence of 19% and 15% were reported among male and female Hmong students, respectively, in another study.30 It is unclear why members of some ethnic groups are at higher risk of HBV infection than others. Further study to investigate the association between cultural, environment, and behavioral factors and HBV exposure is needed to provide evidence-based in development of HBV prevention strategy.

The pooled data from 3 community-based studies showed that overall HBsAg prevalence is higher in males than in females (15% vs 11%, P < .001).8,9,19 Among these 3 studies only 1 study found a significant difference in HBsAg prevalence between males and females whereas the other 2 found the difference to be insignificant. In the study by Hipgrave et al,3 only teenage males had higher rates of current HBV infection and current or past HBV infection than in females (adjusted P < .01).

sec.title: HBV-Related Liver Disease Burden in Vietnam: Current and Future Challenges
sec.p: Chronic HBV infection is the most important cause of liver disease in Vietnam. Although data on resultant HBV-related liver disease burden are very limited and mainly obtained from hospital-based studies, cross-sectional studies found that 42% to 50% of patients with viral hepatitis, 47.8% to 87.6% of patients with liver cirrhosis, and 34.8% to 80.0% of patients with HCC were positive for HBsAg (Table 2). In addition, genotype C (25.1%) and genotype D (20.3%) are the most common genotypes in HBV-infected Vietnamese individuals, and they are both strongly correlated to liver cirrhosis and HCC development.52

Population-based cancer registry studies have reported that age-standardized incidence rates of liver cancer (per 100 000) were 25.3 for males and 5.9 for females in Ho Chi Minh city62 and 14.0 for males and 3.7 for females in Hanoi.63 The age-standardized incidence rate of HCC per 100 000 people with positive HBsAg in the Hanoi population was estimated to be 166 for males and 58 for females.64 These figures were estimated based on cancer registry notifications, which in Vietnam are likely to be underreported and therefore would underestimate HBV-related HCC incidence.

High prevalence of HBsAg with predominance of genotypes B, C, and D, large population, and long latency of HBV-related liver disease development contribute to a heavy burden on health and economic sectors. As HBV infection is not a notifiable disease in Vietnam, data on morbidity as well as mortality of HBV-related liver disease at national level are not available. A recent study using mathematical modeling reported that Vietnam was facing an enormous HBV-related liver disease burden.2 The estimated number of persons with chronic HBV infection in Vietnam increased from 6.4 million cases in 1990 to 8.4 million in 2005. A slight decrease in chronic HBV prevalence could be only observed between 2003 (8.6 million cases) and 2025 (8 million cases). Incidence of HBV-related liver cirrhosis, HCC, and HBV-related mortality was predicted to increase significantly in the next 15 years. Estimated number of HBV-related LC, HCC, and HBV-related deaths increased from 36 500, 15 600, and 23 300 in 2005 to 58 600, 25 000, and 40 000 in 2025, respectively.2

sec.title: Public Health Response to HBV Infection in Vietnam
sec.p: Currently, HBV control in Vietnam relies heavily on universal infant vaccination program, introduced in late 2003, and HBsAg screening for blood donors introduced in the 1990s. Although the coverage rate of HBV vaccination reported is as high as 93% (2006)45 the reduction in prevalence of HBV infection would only be observed in the cohort born from 2003 onward; therefore, as reported in a previous article, the reduction in HBV prevalence of the general population would be insignificant in the next 15 years.2 HBV exposure increased with age and high rates of HBsAg positivity in teenagers, adolescent groups, and those in the age group of 20 to 29 years indicating that horizontal transmission is an important route in spreading HBV. Catch-up vaccination program for children and teenagers born before introducing universal infant HBV vaccination program could prevent horizontal transmission and reduce chronic HBV prevalence more rapidly. However, catch-up vaccination is not currently available for children or teenagers in Vietnam. Lack of knowledge on HBV infection and high cost of HBV vaccine are obstacles for voluntarily vaccination among children and adolescents.

Apart from mother-to-child transmission, household contact has been reported as an independent risk factor for HBV infection, particularly among siblings.8,20 Transmission related to health care, including hospital admission, acupuncture, and medical injection is also documented.8,9,20 However, information on HBV prevention such as brochures, pamphlets, posters, is not available to the public. HBV awareness, therefore, is very low. A survey on knowledge of HBV transmission conducted among heads of household found that less than 12% of 450 respondents had correct answers.20 Improving infection control in health care settings could reduce iatrogenic transmission. Free HBV vaccination should be provided for health care workers to reduce potential transmission between care providers and patients. Our survey on patients’ medical records in a provincial hospital in 2005 found that although almost 100% of patients with liver disease in the Department of Communicable Diseases had been tested for HBsAg, only 51% (119/233) of patients with liver disease in the Department of Internal Medicine and Department of Surgery had received such tests (unpublished data). This suggested a lack of knowledge on HBV information among physicians who are not specialists in communicable diseases. Although, overall HBsAg prevalence in HCWs is similar to that in general population, it was higher in HWS who had direct contact with patients (8.9%) compared with those who had indirect contact with patients (6.3%).40 Low rate of HBV vaccination and lack of HBV knowledge among HCWs were found in a study by Nguyen.40 Only 38.6% of 669 HCWs reported having HBV vaccination. Misconception about HBV transmission and lack of knowledge on progression of HBV infection among HCWs was also reported in this study. For instance, 36% HCWs thought HBV could spread through breast milk, and 17.6% thought HBV could be transmitted through food. Routes of HBV transmission as direct contact with blood or body fluid, sexual activities, and mother-to-child were reported by 88%, 87%, and 78%, respectively, of HCWs. Only 58% to 76% of HCWS knew that HBV infection could lead to chronic hepatitis, liver cirrhosis, and liver cancer.40 Providing knowledge on HBV infection and guidelines on HBV prevention and infection control for health care workers would increase the early detection of HBV infection among patients as well as reduce transmission between patient and care provider in both directions and between patients. Distribution of HBV prevention through different channels, including radio, television, newspapers, brochures, and pamphlets would increase HBV awareness and promote behavior or lifestyles changes and minimize HBV transmission.

There are no data on the rate of people with chronic HBV infection receiving antiviral therapy but presumably, the figure would be very small because of the expensive treatment, high cost of laboratory tests, and whether or not they are aware of their infection status. The consequences of chronic HBV infection among 8 million people currently infected would be a huge burden on economic and health sectors in the future. Increasing the rate of antiviral treatment for people with chronic HBV infection could reduce incidence of liver cirrhosis and HCC. Yet again, with average income per capita per month in 2006 being VND 636 500 (approximately US$40 at exchange rate in 2006),66 antiviral treatment would be unaffordable for many as it is not subsidized by the government.

sec.title: Recommendations
sec.p: A strong advocacy campaign for HBV prevention and control needs to be launched to draw attention from the government and Ministry of Health, in particular. A national strategy for HBV prevention and control needs to be urgently established to undertake HBV prevention measures. With a national strategy for HBV prevention and control, systematic measures could be undertaken, including increasing awareness among health workers through the production of national guidelines, training courses, or continuing education. Information on HBV also needs to be disseminated widely among the public through mass media. Besides maintaining high coverage rate of 3-dose HBV (Hep3) immunization among infants, providing a birth dose within 24 hours of birth is also crucial in protecting infants against HBV infection. Although the first dose has been given in a timely manner in most of national and provincial hospitals, it has usually been delayed if infants born in districts hospital or community health centers. Antenatal screening and providing HBIg (hepatitis B specific immune globulin) should be considered for infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers where resources are available. Epidemiological studies on HBV infection, particularly longitudinal studies on HBV-related liver disease, at a population level are required. Such information is essential for planning HBV-related public health services and for the evaluation of the impact of HBV vaccination programs in Vietnam. Currently, HBV prevention and control is underfunded by the government and receives little support from international agencies. With current limited resources, integration HIV control activities with HBV prevention measures funded by either government or international agencies could be advocated. A model similar to reduced prices of antiviral drugs for HIV/AIDS by pharmaceutical companies could be applied to antiviral drugs for HBV treatment.

In conclusion, HBV-related liver disease is and will continue to create a heavy burden for public health in Vietnam in the next several decades unless appropriate interventions are undertaken urgently. HBV prevention and control should be considered a priority in the agenda of the Ministry of Health of Vietnam. To this end, the establishment of a national strategy for HBV prevention and control is a crucial step. The national strategy for HBV prevention and control should link to other national strategies, including the National Strategy on HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control and the National Immunisation Program.
